raw_text: Results of testing the first stage of this model, the lexical pattern matcher, are reported in (Bear et al, 1992): 309 of 406 utterance containing ' nontrivial ' repairs in their 10,718 utterance corpus were correctly identified, while 191 fluent utterances were incorrectly identified as containing repairs
clean_text: Results of testing the first stage of this model, the lexical pattern matcher, are reported in (Bear et al, 1992): 309 of 406 utterance containing nontrivial  repairs in their 10,718 utterance corpus were correctly identified, while 191 fluent utterances were incorrectly identified as containing repairs.

raw_text: Bear et al (1992) also speculate that acoustic information might be used to filter out false positives for candidates matching two of their lexical patterns- repetitions of single words and cases of single inserted words- but do not report such experimentation
clean_text: Bear et al (1992) also speculate that acoustic information might be used to filter out false positives for candidates matching two of their lexical patterns - repetitions of single words and cases of single inserted words - but do not report such experimentation.

raw_text: As noted in (Bear et al, 1992), knowledge about the location of word fragments would be an invaluable cue to both detection and correction of dis fluencies
clean_text: As noted in (Bear et al, 1992), knowledge about the location of word fragments would be an invaluable cue to both detection and correction of disfluencies.

raw_text: For annotating speech repairs, we have extended the scheme proposed by Bear et al (1992) so that it better deals with overlapping and ambiguous repairs
clean_text: For annotating speech repairs, we have extended the scheme proposed by Bear et al (1992) so that it better deals with overlapping and ambiguous repairs.

citing_paper_authors: Joungbum, Kim | Sarah E., Schwarm | Mari, Ostendorf
raw_text: Bear et al (1992) explored pattern matching, parsing and acoustic cues and concluded that multiple sources of information would be needed to detect edit dis fluencies
clean_text: Bear et al (1992) explored pattern matching, parsing and acoustic cues and concluded that multiple sources of information would be needed to detect edit dis fluencies.

citing_paper_authors: Peter A., Heeman | James F., Allen
raw_text: The SRI group (Bear et al, 1992) employed simple pattern matching techniques for detecting and correcting modification repairs
clean_text: The SRI group (Bear et al, 1992) employed simple pattern matching techniques for detecting and correcting modification repairs.

citing_paper_authors: Mark G., Core | Lenhart K., Schubert
raw_text: (Hindle, 1983) and (Bear et al., 1992) performed speech repair identification in their parsers, and removed the corrected material (reparandum) from consideration
clean_text: (Hindle, 1983) and (Bear et al., 1992) performed speech repair identification in their parsers, and removed the corrected material (reparandum) from consideration.

citing_paper_authors: Mark G., Core | Lenhart K., Schubert
raw_text: This approach is similar to an experiment in (Bear et al, 1992) except that Bear et al were more interested in reducing false alarms
clean_text: This approach is similar to an experiment in (Bear et al, 1992) except that Bear et al were more interested in reducing false alarms.

raw_text: Early work in this field is primarily based on small and proprietary corpora, which makes the comparison of the proposed methods difficult [Young and Matessa 1991, Bear et al 1992, Heeman& amp; Allen 1994]
